chapter.title: Evolution: E-Mailing and Calendaring
chapter.para: Evolution makes the tasks of storing, organizing, and retrieving your personal information easy, so you can work and communicate more effectively with others. It is a professional groupware program and an integral part of the Internet-connected desktop.

Evolution can help you work in a group by handling e-mail, contact information, and one or more calendars. It can do that on one or several computers, connected directly or over a network, for one person or for large groups.

Evolution helps you accomplish common daily tasks. For example, you can easily reuse appointment or contact information sent to you by e-mail, or send e-mail to a contact or appointment. If you receive lots of e-mail, you can use advanced features like search folders, which let you save searches as though they were ordinary e-mail folders.
This chapter introduces you to Evolution and helps you get started. For more details, refer to the Evolution documentation.

sect1.title: Starting Evolution
sect1.para: To start the Evolution client click Applications Internet Evolution .

sect1.title: Setup Assistant
sect1.para: The first time you run Evolution, it opens an assistant to help you set up e-mail accounts and import data from other applications.
The Evolution Account Assistant helps you to provide all the required information.

sect2.title: Restoring from a Backup File
sect2.para: When the First-Run Assistant starts, the Welcome page is displayed. Click Continue to proceed to the Restore from Backup page. If you previously backed up your Evolution configuration and want to restore it, check Restore Evolution from the Backup File. Then, select the backup file in the file chooser dialog. Or click Continue and proceed to the Identity Window.

sect2.title: Defining Your Identity
sect2.para: The Identity Window is the next step in the assistant.

step.para: Type your full name in the Full Name field.
Type your e-mail address in the E-mail Address field.
(Optional) Type a reply to address in the Reply-To field.
Only use this field if you want replies to e-mails sent to a different address.
(Optional) Type your organization name in the Organization field.
This is the company where you work, or the organization you represent when you send e-mails.
Click Continue.

sect2.title: Receiving Mail
sect2.para: The Receiving E-mail option lets you determine the server where you want to receive your e-mail.
You need to specify the type of server you want to receive mail from. If you are not sure about the type of server, contact your system administrator or e-mail provider.
Select a server type in the Server Type list. The following is a list of available server types:

formalpara.title: Exchange Web Services:
formalpara.para: Allows you to connect to newer Microsoft Exchange servers to synchronize e-mail, calendar, and contact information. Available only if you have installed the connector for Microsoft* Exchange* which is packaged in evolution-ews.

formalpara.title: IMAP+:
formalpara.para: Keeps the e-mail on your server so you can access your e-mail from multiple systems.

formalpara.title: POP:
formalpara.para: Downloads your e-mail to your hard disk for permanent storage, freeing up space on the e-mail server.

formalpara.title: USENET News:
formalpara.para: Connects to the news server and downloads a list of available news digests.

formalpara.title: Local Delivery:
formalpara.para: If you want to move e-mail from the spool and store it in your home directory, you need to provide the path to the mail spool you want to use. If you want to leave mail in your systemâ€™s spool files, choose the Standard Unix Mbox Spool File option instead.

formalpara.title: MH Format Mail Directories:
formalpara.para: If you want to download your e-mail using mh or another MH-style program, you need to provide the path to the mail directory you want to use.

formalpara.title: Maildir Format Mail Directories:
formalpara.para: If you download your e-mail using Qmail or another Maildir-style program, you should use this option. You need to provide the path to the mail directory you want to use.

formalpara.title: Standard Unix Mbox Spool File or Directory:
formalpara.para: If you want to read and store e-mail in the mail spool on your local system, choose this option. You need to provide the path to the mail spool you want to use.

formalpara.title: None:
formalpara.para: If you do not plan to check e-mail with this account, select this option. There are no configuration options.

sect3.title: Configuration Options for IMAP+, POP, and USENET
sect3.para: If you have selected IMAP+, POP, or USENET News as the server type, you need to specify additional information.
If you are not sure about the correct server address, user name or security setting, contact your system administrator or e-mail provider.

step.para: Type the host name of your e-mail server in the Server box.
Type your user name for the account in the Username box.
Choose a security setting supported by your mail server. For security reasons, avoid using No Encryption.

Select your authentication type in the Authentication list. To have Evolution check for supported authentication types, click Check for Supported Types. Then choose one of the options without a strikeout.
Some servers do not announce the authentication mechanisms they support. Therefore clicking this button is not a guarantee that available mechanisms actually work.
Click Continue.

sect3.title: Configuration Options for Exchange Web Services
sect3.para: If you have selected Exchange Web Services as the server type, you need to specify additional information.
If you are not sure about the correct server address, user name or security setting, contact your system administrator or e-mail provider.

step.para: Type your user name for the account in the Username box.
Type the EWS URL of your e-mail server in the Host URL box.
If available, type the address of an Offline Address Book into the OAB URL box.
If your login name and the name of your mailbox differ, select Open Mailbox of other user. Then type the mailbox name into the input box below.

Select an authentication type in the Authentication list. To have Evolution check for supported authentication types, click Check for Supported Types. Then choose one of the options without a strikeout.
Some servers do not announce the authentication mechanisms they support. Therefore clicking this button is not a guarantee that available mechanisms actually work.
Click Continue.

sect3.title: Local Configuration Options
sect3.para: If you selected Local Delivery, MH-Format Mail Directories, Maildir-Format Mail Directories, or Standard Unix Mbox Spool File or Directory, specify the path to the local files or directories in the path field.

sect2.title: Receiving Options
sect2.para: After you have selected a mail delivery mechanism, you can set some preferences for its behavior.

sect3.title: IMAP+ Receiving Options
sect3.para: If you have selected IMAP+ as the receiving server type, you will now see a page of options to specify the behavior of Evolution.

step.para: You can choose from the following options:

term.guimenu: Check for new messages every ... minutes

listitem.para: Select if you want Evolution to automatically check for new mail. Set how often to check.

term.guimenu: Check for new message in all folders

listitem.para: Select if you want to check for new messages in all folders.

term.guimenu: Check for new message in subscribed folders

listitem.para: Select if you want to check for new messages in subscribed folders.

term.guimenu: Use Quick Resync if the server supports it

listitem.para: Select if you want to use Quick Resync which makes browsing mail faster on supported servers.

term.guimenu: Listen for server change notifications

listitem.para: Select if you want Evolution to listen for change notifications. If you enable this option, Evolution will try to show you mail as it arrives. Therefore, you can usually deactivate Check for new messages every ... minutes.

term.guimenu: Show only subscribed folders

listitem.para: Select if you want Evolution to show only subscribed folders.
Subscribed folders are folders that you have chosen to receive mail from by subscribing to them.

term.guimenu: Apply filters to new messages in all folders

listitem.para: Select if you want to apply filters to new messages, and whether to do so in all folders or only in the inbox folder.

term.guimenu: Check new messages for Junk contents

listitem.para: Select if you want to check new messages for junk content, and whether to do so in all folders or only in the inbox folder.

term.guimenu: Automatically synchronize remote mail locally

listitem.para: Select this to download all your mail, so you can read it offline.

step.para: Click Continue.

sect3.title: POP Receiving Options
sect3.para: If you have selected POP as the receiving server type, you will now see a page of options to specify the behavior of Evolution.

step.para: You can choose from the following options:

term.guimenu: Check for new messages every ... minutes

listitem.para: Select if you want Evolution to automatically check for new mail. Set how often to check.

term.guimenu: Leave messages on server

listitem.para: Select if you want leave your mail on the server or delete it on the server when you download it to your computer. You can also set a period of time for which the messages will be kept on the server after they were downloaded.

term.guimenu: Disable support for all POP3 extensions

listitem.para: Disabling POP3 extensions can help with old or misconfigured servers. Select if you have trouble receiving mail.

step.para: Click Continue.

sect3.title: USENET News Receiving Options
sect3.para: If you have selected USENET News as the receiving server type, you will now see a page of options to specify the behavior of Evolution.

step.para: You can choose from the following options:

term.guimenu: Check for new messages every ... minutes

listitem.para: Select if you want Evolution to automatically check for new mail. Set how often to check.

term.guimenu: Apply filters to new messages in all folders

listitem.para: Select if you want to apply filters to new messages.

term.guimenu: Show folders in short notations

listitem.para: Abbreviate folder names, for example, comp.os.linux appears as c.o.linux.

term.guimenu: In the subscription dialog, show relative folder names

listitem.para: If you select showing relative folder names in the subscription page, only the name of the folder is displayed. For example, the folder evolution.mail would appear as evolution.

step.para: Click Continue.

sect3.title: Exchange Web Services Receiving Options
sect3.para: If you have selected Exchange Web Services as the receiving server type, you will now see a page of options to specify the behavior of Evolution.

step.para: You can choose from the following options:

term.guimenu: Check for new messages every ... minutes

listitem.para: Select if you want Evolution to automatically check for new mail. Set how often to check.

term.guimenu: Check for new message in all folders

listitem.para: Select if you want to check for new messages in all folders.

term.guimenu: Apply filters to new messages in all folders

listitem.para: Select if you want to apply filters to new messages.

term.guimenu: Check new messages for Junk contents

listitem.para: Select if you want to check new messages for junk content, and whether to do so in all folders or only in the inbox folder.

term.guimenu: Automatically synchronize remote mail locally

listitem.para: Select this to download all your mail, so you can read it offline.

term.guimenu: Connection timeout (in seconds)

listitem.para: Set maximum time to wait for an answer from the server.

term.guimenu: Cache offline address book

listitem.para: If you provided an OAB URL in the prior step, you can select caching an address book. This will make the address book available when offline.

step.para: Click Continue.

sect3.title: Local Delivery Receiving Options
sect3.para: If you have selected that you want to receive mail through Local Delivery, you will now see a page of options to specify the behavior of Evolution.

step.para: Select Check for new messages every ... minutes if you want Evolution to automatically check for new mail. Set how often to check.
Click Continue.

sect3.title: MH-Format Mail Directories Receiving Options
sect3.para: If you have selected that you want to receive mail through MH-Format Mail Directories, you will now see a page of options to specify the behavior of Evolution.

step.para: Select Check for new messages every ... minutes if you want Evolution to automatically check for new mail. Set how often to check.
Select Use the .folders summary file if you want to use the .folders summary file.
Click Continue.

sect3.title: Maildir-Format Mail Directories Receiving Options
sect3.para: If you have selected that you want to receive mail through Maildir-Format Mail Directories, you will now see a page of options to specify the behavior of Evolution.

step.para: Select Check for new messages every ... minutes if you want Evolution to automatically check for new mail. Set how often to check.
Select Apply filters to new messages in Inbox if you want to apply filters to new messages.
Click Continue.

sect3.title: Standard Unix Mbox Spool or Directory Receiving Options
sect3.para: If you have selected that you want to receive mail through a Unix mbox Spool File or Directories, you will now see a page of options to specify the behavior of Evolution.

step.para: Select Check for new messages every ... minutes if you want Evolution to automatically check for new mail. Set how often to check.
Select Apply filters to new messages in Inbox if you want to apply filters to new messages.
Select Store status headers in Elm/Pine/Mutt format to store status headers in a way compatible with Elm, Pine, and Mutt.
Click Continue.

sect2.title: Sending Mail
sect2.para:
Now that you have entered information about how you plan to receive mail, Evolution needs to know about how you want to send it. In most cases, a separate server configuration is necessary for this.
In all other cases, this page will be skipped automatically.

step.para: Select a server type from the Server Type list.
The following server types are available:

formalpara.title: Sendmail:
formalpara.para: Uses the Sendmail program to send mail from your system. Sendmail is more flexible, but is not as easy to configure, so you should select this option only if you know how to set up a Sendmail service.

formalpara.title: SMTP:
formalpara.para: Sends mail using a separate mail server. This is the most common choice for sending mail. If you choose SMTP, there are additional configuration options.

step.para: Type the host address in the Server field.
If you are not sure what your host address is, contact your system administrator or e-mail provider.
Select if your server requires authentication.
If you selected that your server requires authentication, you need to provide the following information:
Choose a security setting supported by your mail server. For security reasons, avoid using No Encryption.
Select your authentication type in the Authentication list.
or
Click Check for Supported Types to have Evolution check for supported types. Then choose one of the options without a strikeout.
Some servers do not announce the authentication mechanisms they support. Therefore, clicking this button is not a guarantee that available mechanisms actually work.
Type your user name in the Username field.
Click Continue.

sect2.title: Account Management
sect2.para: Now that you have finished the e-mail configuration process, you need to give the account a name. The name can be any name you prefer. Type your account name on the Name field. Then click Continue.
Finally, click Apply. The Evolution main window will now open for the first time.

sect1.title: Using Evolution: An Overview
sect1.para: Now that the first-run configuration has finished, you are ready to begin using Evolution. Here is a quick explanation of what is happening in your main Evolution window.
The menu bar gives you access to nearly all of Evolution features.
The folder list gives you a list of the available folders for each account. To see the contents of a folder, click the folder name. The contents are displayed in the e-mail list.
The toolbar gives you fast and easy access to the frequently used features in each component.

The search tool lets you search for e-mails either in the current account or in all accounts. You can filter e-mails, contacts, calendar entries and tasks using different criteria. The Search tool can also save frequently used searches to a search folder.

The message list displays a list of e-mails that you have received. The radio button above the list lets you view massages according to predefined and custom labels. To view an e-mail in the preview pane, select the e-mail.

The shortcut bar lets you switch between folders. At the bottom of the shortcut bar there are tool buttons that let you switch tools, and above that is a list of all the available folders for the current tool. If you have the Evolution Connector for Microsoft Exchange installed, you have an Exchange button in addition to buttons for the other tools.

The statusbar periodically displays a message, or tells you the progress of a task. This most often happens when you are checking or sending e-mail. These progress queues are shown in the previous figure. The Online/Offline indicator is here, too, in the lower left of the window.
The preview pane displays the contents of the e-mails that are selected in the e-mail list.

sect2.title: The Menu Bar
sect2.para: The menu barâ€™s contents always provide all the possible actions for any given view of your data. If you are looking at your INBOX, most of the menu items relate to e-mail. Some content relates to other components of Evolution and some, especially those in the File menu, relates to the application as a whole.

formalpara.title: File:
formalpara.para: Anything related to a file or to the operations of the application usually falls under this menu, such as creating things, saving them to disk, printing them, and quitting the program itself.

formalpara.title: Edit:
formalpara.para: Contains useful tools that help you edit text and move it around. Lets you access the settings and configuration options in the Edit menu.

formalpara.title: View:
formalpara.para: Lets you decide how Evolution should look. Some of the features control the appearance of Evolution as a whole, and others the way a particular kind of information appears.

formalpara.title: Folder:
formalpara.para: Contains actions that can be performed on folders. You can find things like copy, rename, delete, etc.

formalpara.title: Message:
formalpara.para: Contains actions that can be applied to a message. If there is only one target for the action (such as replying to a message), you can normally find it in the Message menu.

formalpara.title: Search:
formalpara.para: Lets you search for messages, or phrases within a message. You can also see previous searches you have made. In addition to the Search menu, there is a text box in the toolbar that you can use to search for messages. You can also create a search folder from a search.

formalpara.title: Help:
formalpara.para: Opens the Evolution Help files.

sect2.title: The Shortcut Bar
sect2.para: Evolutionâ€™s most important task is to give you access to your information and help you use it quickly. One way it does that is through the shortcut bar, which is the column on the left side of the main window. The buttons, such as Mail and Contacts, are the shortcuts. Above them is a list of folders for the selected Evolution tool.

The folder list organizes your e-mail, calendars, contact lists, and task lists in a tree, similar to a file tree. Most people find one to four folders at the base of the tree, depending on the tool and their system configuration. Each Evolution tool has at least one, called On This Computer, for local information. For example, the folder list for the e-mail tool shows any remote e-mail storage you have set up, plus local folders and search folders.
If you get large amounts of e-mail, you might want to create more folders than your INBOX. You can create multiple e-mail folders, address books, calendars, task lists, or memo lists.
To create a new folder:

step.para: Click File NewMail Folder .
Type the name of the folder in the Folder Name field.
Select the location of the new folder.
Click Create.

sect3.title: Folder Management
sect3.para: Right-click a folder or subfolder to display a menu with the following options:

formalpara.title: New Folder:
formalpara.para: Creates a new folder or subfolder in the same location.

formalpara.title: Copy:
formalpara.para: Copies the folder to a different location. When you select this item, Evolution offers a choice of locations to copy the folder to.

formalpara.title: Move:
formalpara.para: Moves the folder to another location.

formalpara.title: Delete:
formalpara.para: Deletes the folder and all contents.

formalpara.title: Mark Messages As Read:
formalpara.para: Marks all the messages in the folder as read.

formalpara.title: Rename:
formalpara.para: Lets you change the name of the folder.

formalpara.title: Refresh:
formalpara.para: Refreshes the folder.

formalpara.title: Properties:
formalpara.para: Checks the number of total and unread messages in a folder and, for remote folders, lets you select whether to copy the folder to your local system for offline operation.

sect3.para: You can also rearrange folders and messages by dragging and dropping them.
Any time new e-mail arrives in a e-mail folder, that folder label is displayed in bold text, along with the number of new messages in that folder.

sect2.title: E-Mail
sect2.para: Evolution e-mail is like other e-mail programs in several ways:

listitem.para: It can send and receive e-mail in HTML or as plain text, and makes it easy to send and receive multiple file attachments.
It supports multiple e-mail sources, including IMAP, POP3, and local Mbox or mh spools and files created by other e-mail programs.
It can sort and organize your e-mail in a wide variety of ways with folders, searches, and filters.
It lets you guard your privacy with encryption.

sect2.para: However, Evolution differs from other e-mail programs in some very essential ways. First, it is built to handle very large amounts of e-mail. The junk e-mail, message filtering and searching functions were built for speed and efficiency. There is also the search folder, an advanced organizational feature not found in some e-mail clients. If you get a lot of e-mail, or if you keep every message you get in case you need to refer to it later, you will find this feature especially useful. Here is a quick explanation of what is happening in your main Evolution e-mail window. You can also run Evolution now in Windows.

The message list displays all the e-mails that you have. This includes all your read and unread messages and e-mail that is flagged to be deleted. With the Show radio button above the message you can filter the message list view using several predefined and custom labels.
This is where your e-mail is displayed.

If you find the preview pane too small, you can resize the pane, enlarge the whole window, or double-click the message in the message list to have it open in a new window. To change the size of a pane, drag the divider between the two panes.

As with folders, you can right-click messages in the message list and get a menu of possible actions, including moving or deleting them, creating filters or search folders based on them, and marking them as junk mail.
E-mail-related actions, like Reply and Forward, appear as buttons in the toolbar and are also located in the right-click menu and as key combinations.
Evolution allows you to create and edit message templates that you can use at any time to send mail with the same pattern.

sect2.title: The Calendar
sect2.para: To begin using the calendar, click Calendars in the shortcut bar. By default, the calendar shows todayâ€™s schedule on a ruled background. At the upper right, there is a Tasks list, where you can keep a list of tasks separate from your calendar appointments. Below that, thereâ€™s a list for memos.
The appointment list displays all your scheduled appointments.
The month pane is a small view of a calendar month. You can also select a range of days in the month pane to display a custom range of days in the appointment list.
Tasks are distinct from appointments because they generally do not have times associated with them. You can see a larger view of your task list by clicking Tasks in the shortcut bar.
Memos, like Tasks, do not have times associated with them. You can see a larger view of your Memo list by clicking Memos in the shortcut bar.

sect2.title: The Contacts Tool
sect2.para: The Evolution contacts tool can handle all of the functions of an address book or phone book. However, it is easier to update Evolution than it is to change an actual paper book, in part because Evolution can synchronize with Palm OS&thrdmrk; devices and use LDAP directories on a network.

Another advantage of the Evolution contacts tool is its integration with the rest of the application. For example, you can right-click an e-mail address in Evolution mail to instantly create a contact entry.

To use the contacts tool, click Contacts in the shortcut bar. By default, the display shows all your contacts in alphabetical order, in a minicard view. You can select other views from the View menu, and adjust the width of the columns by clicking and dragging the gray column dividers.

The largest section of the contacts display shows a list of individual contacts. You can also search the contacts in the same way that you search e-mail folders, using the search tool on the right side of the toolbar.
